awd_titl_txt: NSF I-Corps: Silver materials for antimicrobial coatings
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a new means of creating broad-spectrum antimicrobial fabric treatments with a low barrier to entry for manufacturers. This technology promises to deliver antimicrobial coatings at lower overall economic and environmental costs, by reducing solvent usage, waste, and coating loss. Antimicrobial treatments are already used in medicine, as anti-infective treatments of bandages, catheters, and other medical items, and in garments and textiles, as anti-odor treatments. The lower barrier to entry for garment manufacturers is expected to enable more widespread adoption of the technology, which in turn will reduce material and energy waste from excessive laundering and save consumers money. The technology can be adapted to a wide range of fiber types and can be applied without specialized equipment, facilitating the integration into existing manufacturing processes and giving manufacturers access to premium market segments with minimal upfront investment. 


This I-Corps project will help improve the market penetration of antimicrobial treatments, which in turn will provide consumers with superior garment performance at reduced environmental and economic costs. The technology uses a new form of soluble silver metal, developed by prior NSF funded research, and an innovative method to coat a variety of different fiber types with bioactive silver, which enables the antimicrobial coatings to be applied at any stage in the manufacturing process. Proof of concept has been demonstrated with basic prototyping, but development of the technology for specific markets and applications demands a better understanding of customer needs. This I-Corps team project is aimed at discovering those customer needs, through extensive customer interviews, in order to inform the development and engineering of products that meet each particular market specific need that is identified.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to understand how our anti-microbial coating technology could be translated into the marketplace, with additional goals of training and professional development of the iCorps team members and the development of relationships that would aid in the technology development and transfer. Through the iCorps process of customer discovery interviews, as well as through subsequent meetings and relationships derived from the iCorps process, we navigated our way through a few different commercial possibilities to settle on an anti-odor application for garment manufacturers. We identified a commercial opportunity to provide a high-performing fabric treatment at a lower price and in a product that could be easily integrated into standard manufacturing processes. As a result, we have been working with industry in test production runs to test and improve this technology in order to translate it into the marketplace.

This project has several broader impacts. Frist, it would yield new jobs and economic impact from the successful commercialization of the coating, not just for the manufacture of the coating but also for the companies that use it. Also, consumer end users should benefit from higher quality goods, and potentially fewer washings and longer garment life, both of which are environmentally desirable. Finally, with regard to training, two of the iCorps team members have since moved on to other small companies, where their iCorps experience has helped them contribute to their growth and development. Other students in the Bigioni lab have also been exposed to this project and continue to learn and benefit from this new industrial relationship. Certainly, this iCorps project will have a long-lasting effect on how we think about our science and materials in terms of its broader impact on the world.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/09/2022
Modified by: Terry P Bigioni
